text: RihuÄ«-rihuÄ setah alÅ«n.
trns: I am drinking (water) repeatedly.
expl: The prompt specifies what I assume is iterative. I mused over a few ideas on how to indicate this, and settled on expanding off of a previous construction (become/grow more and more ...) which uses a raised, reduplicated adverbial form of the verb. The '(to become/grow) more and more' construction can be easily re-analyzed as derivative of an iterative mood since the construction uses the auxiliary -latÄ 'it becomes (it),' for example: renÄ«-renlatÄ“ 'it became better and better.'

text: TÂ²Ä nÄ“lÄ essÄ“ setÂ²ahÂ² tapÄ ya mÂ²etÂ²ahÂ² rizquetÂ²en in xeih sorÄ«n, ko cÄ“z tÂ²Ä carÄ essÄ“ mÂ²etÂ²ahÂ² nÅi.
trns: I really do think you need a mentor and lots of love, because you do seem very angry.
expl: This exemplifies the use of tÄ i.e. the copula as a clausal intensifier. In English, the intensivity is given by 'do,' as in 'I do think ...' rather than 'I think,' which is fairly neutral. The literal translation is 'it is that I think ...' for tÄ nÄ“lÄ (setah). Note also that 'very' and 'really' (in the sense of an intensifier) are lexified equally - this reflects the more overarching nature that verbs and adjectives are not grammatically distinguished.

text: Petlo mÂ²enari in nader mÂ²enari; sopenÄ tÄ«Ä“.
trns: Thy rod and thy staff; they comfort me.
expl:
Translating this one involved deciding between a formal and personal second person for 'thy.' In normal speech 'your' is an affix upon the noun (i.e. mepetlo in menader) but in order to respect the gravitas of the original, I chose to use the formal menari 'you' << m(e) 'your' + narÄ«n 'clarity' << narÄ 'it is clear.'
It should be noted that in English of the time this was originally written, 'thou' is more personal than 'you,' and in many languages the personal T is used in reference to God. My native language (English) does not make the T-V distinction and my understanding therefore of the distinction is academically derived and conversationally infelicitous.
data: petlo-Ã˜         mÂ²e-nar-i-Ã˜                       in  nader-Ã˜         mÂ²e-nar-i-Ã˜                       s-open-Ä                   tÄ«-Ä“
